In quantum mechanics, the uncertainty principle (also known as Heisenberg's uncertainty principle) is any of a variety of mathematical inequalities asserting a fundamental limit to the precision with which certain pairs of physical properties of a particle, known as complementary variables, such as energy E and time t, can be known. See Uncertainty principle and  “Quantum mechanics [therefore] states that, on a very, very tiny scale and for very, very, very short lengths of time, energy can be spontaneously … created and destroyed. Kind of like boiling water, where bubbles spontaneously appear and burst, energy - in the form of [particle pairs] - can spontaneously appear from the {non empty vacuum} of spacetime, exist for a tremendously short amount of time, and disappear again. On normal time and length scales, this all averages out to what thermodynamics says should be true (that no energy is created or destroyed within the closed system of the universe). But this does mean that, if there was such a tiny fluctuation at the beginning of time, it could have made the total energy of the universe at creation slightly more than zero, and thus the universe will always contain that total amount of energy” See in Ask a Physicist Answers (The total energy of the universe has been calculated to be near zero. See Norman Simenson's answer to Our universe has tremendous gravitational potential energy. Since an input of energy is required to produce a state of potential energy, what would induce a quantum fluctuation of that much energy, especially if the universe is infinite? ) (The Heisenberg uncertainty relation states: delta E x delta t >= h/4pi i.e., that the uncertainty in energy times the uncertainty in time is greater than or equal to Planck’s constant divided by four times pi. Interpreted correctly, this means that it is possible to violate conservation of energy given you do it for a very short time. In other words, it is possible “to borrow" energy E from "nowhere", given that you return it in a time period t, where t is given by t ~ h/E ) This spontaneous creation of energy at the quantum level for the briefest of times is nominally unmeasurable (it is postulated that any variation that changes the action by an amount less than h/4pi cannot be observable )— so is deemed ‘virtual’— NOT ‘real’. But, it does affect events at the quantum level, so is NOT imaginary! However, since everything averages out in the end, the law of conservation of energy is not violated.
